1.piece_medium: mixed media:  painting, cloth, wood head
1.piece_prompt: How does the bear’s head relate to the Venus figure?
1.artist: Tom Sale, John Allen & Trish Nickell
1.collector_notes: This work mimics the art game, Exquisite Corpse, of the 1920s, invented by Marcel Duchamp and the DADAists, to entertain themselves during their social evenings.  On a thrice-folded paper, each drew or painted on only his/her part of the page, hiding their contribution when passing it to the next artist, with only a few marks to show where to continue the drawing.  As you can see in this Exquisite Corpse, the parts hardly relate to each other, but the whole artwork has a charm and curiosity that make it engaging.  The work, created as a result of an art-making project conceived by now UTD chair/professor Rick Brettell, heralded the opening of the McKinney Avenue Contemporary in 1995.

5.piece_prompt: How can such a small work describe a big sky?
5.collector_notes: This small, intimate artwork says a great deal about the vast scale of our wonderful sky.  Artist Ali Akbar found new ways to work with paint, creating slabs of paint on another surface and then dragging it carefully onto a new canvas.  A prolific painter at the time, he returned to his native Bangladesh to continue these precious small works.

50.piece_prompt: What comes to mind about these puddle shapes?
50.collector_notes: This artist endeared himself to all of Dallas as a loving guy who also loved to paint and to teach, as he did influencing bright young students at St Marks School.  His bold, bright, expressive paintings appeared in Pure Paint in 1992, my first curated exhibition at Arlington Museum of Art.  The canvases showed large, explosive areas of puddled paint.  This later work dealt with the cancerous cells he fought at the end of his much-too-short life.

51.piece_prompt: What makes the human form a classic?
51.collector_notes: Bodnar, a skilled printmaker, uses a spare, delicate line to define the figure.  On a black ground with a refined red line, he recalls the classic nude.  I found this charming print at noted Dallas gallerist Laura Carpenter’s space.  In simple refinement it shows the figure’s elegance in a less traditional way.

52.piece_prompt: Knowing these are bags of paint, how do these materials transform/transcend into a sculpture?
52.collector_notes: As a UTD graduate, Breazeale clearly experimented with paint and the notion of being a painter or a sculptor.  In using paint in the most non-traditional way, pouring it into stacked zip-lock bags, he creates a painting and a sculpture simultaneously.  What a clever way to create the two most important art forms in one work of art.  Now the paint has dried in clumps in the bags, but the work lives on in its freshness.

53.piece_prompt: What makes these healing or nurturing hands?

8.piece_prompt: Is this a metaphor? Is this literal? What comes to mind about this white box?

54.piece_prompt: What makes this polyurethane form a painting?
54.collector_notes: This artist, former Dallasite now living in New York, stole time away from his law practice to make serious art.  He found a totally inventive way to make a painting that was not a painting with non-traditional materials.  Using polyester resin in a mold that created a facsimile of an actual stretched canvas, he built surprise mock paintings in ice-cream pastel colors, paintings that became sculpture as well as paintings.

55.piece_prompt: What feelings are provoked when near this cocoon shape?  How different can you imagine your experience is being in the same space with this sculpture versus seeing a reproduction on-line?
55.collector_notes: This petite now-departed woman from the swamps of Louisiana, was 90 years old when she made these elegant figurative forms from the simplest of art materials:  papier maché.  Her elongated, statuesque figures spelled out the mythological stories she remembered from her childhood education.  The small autobiographical figure of the child in the cocooned boat relived the painful wailings of the southern Black women as they swayed in the swamps mourning their losses.

56.piece_prompt: What elements might cause a humorous reaction when looking at this photograph?
56.collector_notes: As a young student at UNT and TWU, Connell interned at Arlington Museum of Art honing her teaching, curatorial, and photography skills.  Then as an early UTD artist-in-residence, Connell continued developing her concept with a favorite Denton model she continues to engage as the doppelganger.  In her own unique way, Connell developed these orchestrated theatrical settings that test the notions of identity.  Her work now receives national attention and clearly straddles the art and tech realm.

57.piece_prompt: How does this sculpture make you think of order?
57.collector_notes: This feisty young artist/curator from Austin pushes the limits of a multiplicity of things.  At Dallas Contemporary he curated an exhibition and produced his own large installation of abandoned, sport trophies engulfing a stairway to imagined notions of fame.  In this piece he illuminates stacks of glass shelves laced with decals pointing to a mysterious focal point.

9.piece_prompt: How do these female forms relate to the trajectory of classical figurative art?
9.collector_notes: This young photographer from south Texas uses a simple pinhole camera.  With this elementary low-tech way of capturing a scene, she gets our attention.  The simplicity and rawness of her medium permit us to accept her humorous and poetic view of women.

10.piece_prompt: What senses does this sculpture engage?
10.collector_notes: Gabriel Dawe first left his native Mexico for England, then Montreal, and finally Dallas to gain his masters degree at UTD and study as an artist-in-residence at CentralTrak.  This early work explores non-traditional materials to comment on life’s everyday difficulties.  Dawe continued to explore handiwork and the use of thread in what has become major installations of laced colored threads that form iridescent backdrops of shaded environments.  It is amazing what this young man has created from the memories of a grandmother who wouldn’t permit him to sew, because she viewed it as a female-gendered activity.

11.piece_prompt: What pleasures might exist in this fabric piece?
11.collector_notes: After having the privilege of visiting Cuba to bring medicines to help their under-prepared communities, I had a special affinity for its people and its culture.  I was drawn to this simple, yet elegant piece at a small early Miami art fair.  Using inexpensive found materials, the artist creates a caring, delicate and sympathetic work.  The fabric, what I imagine is the small floor mat placed next to the bed at night, so one doesn’t touch a cold floor, is then embroidered with the notion of bringing comfort to someone.  She certainly does.

12.piece_prompt: How do these comic shapes related to each other?
12.collector_notes: Since animé became a recognized art movement in Japan, I began watching for area artists who used the comic drawn line in their work.  In this dear drawing/painting, English creates her own unusual characters having tea together in a monochromatic color field.  How delightful to gaze at this scene.

13.piece_prompt: What about this spiked circle would cause you to contemplate human existence?
13.collector_notes: This artwork comes from a major exhibition co-curated with colleague Kevin Mercier at the Arlington Museum of Art that recognized the sesquicentennial between Texas and Mexico.  Mario Rangel Faz was one of the Mexican artists invited to exhibit.  Shopping at the nearby hardware store, Faz purchased barbed wire to create a wall installation.  Upon his departure, he gave me this halo, one from his large circle of halos.

14.piece_prompt: How does this image relate to an individual’s life?
14.collector_notes: An SMU graduate, artist Linda Finnell turned her talents to printmaking.  Upon graduating, Finnell and art buddy Julie Cohn formed Two Women Boxing, an early design-aware business in Dallas, creating artist-made boxes.  Upon Finnell’s early death, Cohn gathered friends to each choose one of Finnell’s artworks.  In this delicate print of a wispy feather, the notion of nature morte, the concept of still-life art acknowledging that all life disintegrates, reminds us of the tenuousness of time.

58.piece_prompt: Why might the concept of death also include a bit of humor?
58.collector_notes: One of the most accomplished North Texas artist/teachers, Vernon Fisher continues to create startling art that causes viewers to ponder and laugh.  Fisher plays with elegantly drawn and painted, found, repurposed imagery and text, cross-fertilizing both image and text to challenge his audience.  In this print, one of a series created as part of a gift to upper level donors at Dallas Contemporary, Fisher tantalizes the viewer with the notion of death and the humor of his imbedded comic characters.

15.piece_medium: oil on canvas (restored cracked paint areas), fr
15.piece_prompt: How would you explain this narrative painting?
15.collector_notes: Barnaby Fitzgerald wields his brush as an elegant neo-Classical painter, creating narrative scenes with beautifully painted figures.  An SMU professor, Fitzgerald lived a magical life in Italy steeped in literary classics while his father spent a career translating the Iliad and the Odyssey.  Fitzgerald’s paintings wrapped in soft, mellow hues tell his personal stories while also hearkening back to classical history.

16.piece_prompt: What makes this small sculpture unexpectedly dynamic?

17.piece_prompt: How do you create a story looking at these disparate parts?
17.collector_notes: Harry Geffert is a master craftsman and sculptor.  In his professionally outfitted foundry, Geffert pours bronze sculptures for the premier artists of the region.  Always open to new ways of making the bronze “talk,” and using his skills and inventiveness, Geffert pushes bronze limits in form and color.  This work was one of his patina samples to show other artists; I had to beg him to sell it to me!  His bronze sculptures play out his childhood memories and dreams.  Laden with nature, furniture, and figures, delicacy meets heavy-handed structures.

18.piece_title: Communication Quarterly 1978 & Southern Speech J, Vol 1954-55
18.piece_prompt: How do the color inserts make you rethink scholarly storage?
18.collector_notes: A TCU arts graduate, Nate Glaspie has focused his visions on making objects that adhere to geometric abstraction.  His simple, elegant forms often use unusual, ready-made objects to add humor and intelligence to his concepts.  Now teaching sculpture in Dallas, his concepts will challenge others’ creative thinking.

19.piece_title: Western Speech Vol J, 1976-79 & Central States Vol J 1978
19.piece_prompt: How do the color inserts make you rethink scholarly storage?

59.piece_prompt: What might this mysterious place be?
59.collector_notes: A recent masters graduate from UTD, Sally Glass (my husband’s daughter) completed her artist residency at CentralTrak.  In this photograph from early in her schooling, Glass challenged herself to create mystery and drama in making the image, using both color and materials in unusual ways.  As a conceptual artist now living in Houston, she continues to invent new approaches using video and sculpture to challenge viewers and self.

60.piece_medium: stitchery on mulberry paper w/ thread
60.piece_prompt: What do these loose threads suggest?
60.collector_notes: Artist Linnea Glatt draws with thread, her sewing machine, and sometimes even a pencil.  In spare and repetitive lines, Glatt creates drawings of global universes that approach space, the environment, and concept.  Every aspect of the drawing concerns her, such as her choice of mulberry paper.  The drawings follow her early work as a sculptor and place-maker.

61.piece_title: From North to South, East to West
61.piece_medium: print& drawing on mulberry paper with thread
61.piece_prompt: How does this geometry define your path?

62.piece_title: No one Would Believe She Was Innocent
62.piece_prompt: What might you surmise about this figure and her circumstance?
62.collector_notes: A photographer and teacher at TWU, Susan Kay Grant makes images that relate to her own memories and dreams.  Using color photography in this early work, Grant subtly confronts women’s issues.  In more recent black-and-white work, she photographs shadowed dramas of silhouetted figures.

63.piece_prompt: How does the size of photograph engage or discourage you?

64.piece_prompt: How do these shapes make you feel?  What do you suppose the artist is trying to say?
64.collector_notes: An SMU art graduate, Lily Hanson found a medium and message clearly her own.  Using fabrics, stuffed forms, and pastel colors, Hansen creates wall sculptures of idiosyncratic shapes.  Her unique bulbous pieces are warm, friendly, and animal-like.  They assume an endearing presence.  It’s no surprise this talented young woman is also a star dessert chef!

65.piece_title: Study of Lies of Sound Memory
65.piece_prompt: How would you describe these objects?
65.collector_notes: Another SMU art graduate, Tracy Harris lived and worked in Dallas before moving to New York.  Now nestled on Long Island, she continues to make drawings and paintings that chart the universe.  The poetic, mechanical drawings she creates resemble serious, buildable forms, but instead become invented magical, contraptions.

66.piece_prompt: What are these drawings saying to you?  Are you ever disappointed when a work is “untitled”?
66.collector_notes: With an artist who grew up in Arlington and lived in Germany, I had the opportunity to co-curate an exhibition at Arlington Museum of Art of fellow German artists whose work deserved attention.  It was refreshing to show German Expressionism, a historical and vital art movement unlike the contemporaneous work in Texas.  HART, an artist in the exhibition, sent me with a portfolio of his drawings, each one delightfully expressive, sensitive, and fresh.

20.piece_medium: wood, fabric, foam core & plastic frame
20.piece_prompt: How do these different parts make up the whole?
20.collector_notes: Artist Joseph Havel’s work hearkens back to his youth in the west in a hard-working family.  His adherence to the reoccurring references to clothing, drapery, and literature symbolize the love and respect of making things with his hands.  In his art, Havel found a connectedness to work shirts and dress labels.  In this piece, he stacks dress labels in a tightly condensed square, making sculpture from unusual materials that read as geometric abstraction.

67.piece_prompt: What’s happening in this colorful sculpture?
67.collector_notes: As a child growing up in San Antonio with Saturday cartoons on television, John Hernandez invents colorful cartoony figures in his 3-D wall sculptures.  The flashy bright palette and brazen dimensionality make the figures jump out from the wall, greeting its audience.  Hernandez always creates a narrative that’s clear to the artist and imagined by the viewer.

21.piece_prompt: How does this work make you consider your role in caretaking?
21.collector_notes: To recognize the Arlington art association’s 40-year anniversary, I invited artists to participate in an auction called 40+ Views.  Jerry Janosco created this decorative metal work with a flouncy skirt to acknowledge the retirement home for Masons in Arlington.  It’s clever construction includes a lit graphic of sensitive caretaking.  When I first saw it, I mistakenly thought he was referencing the girly bars!

68.piece_medium: grip tape, acrylic on acrylic on sheet
68.piece_prompt: How does the hidden glow inform the concept of fractals?
68.collector_notes: San Antonio artist Lawrence Jennings makes art from plastic sheets that read as paintings.  The zigzag edges relate to digital programming and make this work a perfect fit for an art and tech program.  Notice how this piece hovers away from the wall creating a glowing neon-like halo.

22.piece_prompt: How does the shadow affect how you see the horses?
22.collector_notes: A long-time Texas artist, Luis Jimenez sadly died falling from scaffolding while working on a sculpture commission for the Denver airport.  Jimenez’s fine draftsmanship captured the allure of Texas in his spirited drawings of life on the ranch.  Resin-coated, lone star sculptures captured the energy of animals on the plains.  His daughter, Elisa, continues the artistic tradition as an inventive fashion designer.

69.piece_prompt: How do the painted marks affect the pure geometry of circle & rectangle?
69.collector_notes: Seasoned and prolific Texas artist Otis Jones has created his signature objects for years.  In sculptural materials, Jones makes works that read as minimal, non-objective paintings.  With carefully placed markings and paint affixed and scratched away, the artist takes the viewer into the studio, as though observing his intimate process.

23.piece_prompt: How does this drawing speak to you?
23.collector_notes: A draftsman, par excellence, Jose Enrique Krapp built a fascinating construction at Dallas Contemporary on Swiss Avenue.  It looked like a building-in-process, with all its creative possibilities on view.  His drawing served as a study for the sculpture and show the crispness and charm of odd materials together.

70.piece_title: You Quack me uo (1 of a cluster)
70.piece_prompt: How does the ceramic duck affect you?  What is your relationship to this image and has this artwork altered it?
70.collector_notes: A ceramist with a huge sense of humor, artist J Neil Lawley created a flock of ducks.  When this clay duck broke unexpectedly and got separated from the cluster, Lawley gave it to me.  Now sealed and healed, it welcomes all those who enter the building from its north side.

24.piece_prompt: What might the three layers of the grid define?
24.collector_notes: Now based in Denton at UNT, Annette Lawrence’s work appears as sculpture, collage, and drawings.  Using non-traditional materials, Lawrence makes sensitive works from kraft bags, postal cord, and discarded mail that deal with collections and the passage of time.  A major sculpture installation at the Cowboys Stadium, a work using metal cable strung between walls above an entrance shows her boldness in “tying parts together.”

26.piece_prompt: How might this abstraction manage to be decorative and also tell a story?
26.collector_notes: A UTD arts graduate now studying in California, Kirsten Macy makes bold paintings with bright color.  Her glossy color fields create dynamic minimal abstractions that relate to the natural and man-made environment.  These simple geometric landscapes paved the way for her more recent work with subtle color and the natural environment of clouds and weather, though still utilizing abstraction.

71.piece_title: Still Life with Fruit and Zhuang Zi
71.piece_prompt: How does this still life video relay a dramatic narrative?
71.collector_notes: San Antonion Karen Mahaffy’s video, Still Life with Fruit and Zhuang Zi, captivated me.  The stunning imagery follows the traditional concept of still life painting, though in the digital medium of today.  Still life in Latin translates as nature morte, telling us about life’s passing, that all life dies.  Listen carefully:  two people are chatting, sharing intimacies we cannot quite hear, adding to the mysteriousness of the work.

27.piece_prompt: How does the technology of the hologram affect the way the artwork is perceived, considered or consumed?
27.collector_notes: Fort Worth artist Robert McAn worked in photography in his early years as an artist.  In one color photograph, he explores the technique of holography, capturing the three-dimensions of the image; in another, in black-and-white photography, he superimposes revealing symbols.  They are both portraits:  one, an elegant sculpture at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, and the other, his own autobiographical silhouette.

28.piece_prompt: How do the symbols affect the silhouette?

29.piece_prompt: What do these common household materials denote?  Is there symbolism at work?
29.collector_notes: UTD sculpture professor Greg Metz, created this inventive, clever sculpture for his friend Georganne Deen.  Since he donated it to one of Dallas Contemporary’s annual Wish! fundraising auctions, I always thought it was for me.  I actually wore it while organizing the event, parading around the museum like a little elf!  The charming piece exemplifies how one unexpectedly simple work can bring delight to its audience.

72.piece_prompt: How do these animals imply human drama?
72.collector_notes: Well-respected Texas artist Melissa Miller draws and paints animals as though they were human.  Her imagined kingdom of anthropomorphic characters is charming and intoxicating.  In the paintings, luscious paint drips from her brush giving the surface a timeless quality as though she painted the work yesterday.  In drawings and prints, she captures the intimacy and charm of four-legged friends totally engaged.

30.piece_prompt: What might this cacophony of appliances tell you?
30.collector_notes: According to sculptor Mark Monroe, this was the first artwork he’d ever sold.  Now art department head at Austin College in Sherman, Monroe influences a host of young artists at this small liberal arts college.  His adventurous and clever sculpture makes art out of throwaways:  old, large and small appliances, sport equipment, and recycled metals.  This work is kinetic:  flip the switch on the right and be startled as you watch the dated appliances come alive.

31.piece_title: Double Bubble, World War II, Enlightenment  #2
31.piece_medium: collage, mixed media on paper, ed 2/20, fr
31.piece_prompt: How does this piece bring humor and pain to mind?
31.collector_notes: Photographer and printmaker from Arlington, Celia Munoz makes art that relates to her Hispanic life experiences usually with some unexpected humor and pathos.  In this work, she recalls her father’s homecoming after his tour of duty in World War II.  Sharing American bubble gum with small children in Europe endeared them to him.  But then with a twist, the reality of the war becomes part of the story Munoz remembers and shares with us in this artwork.

32.piece_prompt: What could the repetition in this photograph denote?
32.collector_notes: A photographer and fashion designer now living in New York, Murdoch sees the city through her own trained eyes.  Pacing the streets of Manhattan with camera in hand, Murdoch finds and captures unexpected patterns worthy of saving.  In a cutting pattern/cutting edge exhibition held at Arlington Museum of Art, she made sassy, colorful dresses out of “up-cycling” throwaway plastic bags.

73.piece_prompt: Artworks can shift and inhabit several categories.  How can you “read” this work as a painting?
73.collector_notes: Young artist Laura Neaderhouser began making “paintings” out of wool when she visited with her friend’s mom-in-mourning.  During the visits, Neaderhouser learned and began to knit and crochet.  She realized she could create a colorful visual field, much as she did in painting, using a different and unusual material.  The resulting work is fresh and alive.

74.piece_prompt: What does the repeated design tell you about the artist?
74.collector_notes: Dallas artist Tom Orr participated as one of the invited artists who published prints as gifts to donors at Dallas Contemporary.  The repeated, quadraphonic image of his fingerprint stunningly exemplifies organic and concentric patterning.  The print evidences Orr’s usual work as a minimal sculptor in which he repeats simple form.  His three-dimensional work often creates a rhythmic moiré pattern (as you might see in lush taffeta fabric).  His large-scale outdoor sculpture appears at the Love Field entrance, and an indoor installation at DFW welcomes travelers at the International terminal.

75.piece_prompt: How does the repetition in this print affect your visual perception?
75.collector_notes: Long-time UTD art professor John Pomara began in the early 90s as a painter, making large-scale diptych paintings.  One of the dueling sides of this early work always included a metallic half, with the two halves “talking” to each other.  The large green and silver painting from the Seth Davidow Collection appeared in the first exhibition I curated at Arlington Museum of Art called Pure Paint.  Another early two-part piece, painting and wood, shows his affinity for duality in his work.  Becoming more connected to the digital world, he created the two small photo-based works from Dallas Contemporary’s print series in which every image is completely different.

33.piece_medium: mixed media on canvas & wood (2 pieces)
33.piece_prompt: How do the painted & wood segments complement each other?
33.collector_notes: Long-time UTD art professor John Pomara began in the early 90s as a painter, making large-scale diptych paintings.  One of the dueling sides of this early work always included a metallic half, with the two halves “talking” to each other.  The large green and silver painting from the Seth Davidow Collection appeared in the first exhibition I curated at Arlington Museum of Art called Pure Paint.  Another early two-part piece, painting and wood, shows his affinity for duality in his work.  Becoming more connected to the digital world, he created the two small photo-based works from Dallas Contemporary’s print series in which every image is completely different.

34.piece_prompt: How does this double painting (diptych) relate to the landscape?
34.collector_notes: Long-time UTD art professor John Pomara began in the early 90s as a painter, making large-scale diptych paintings.  One of the dueling sides of this early work always included a metallic half, with the two halves “talking” to each other.  The large green and silver painting from the Seth Davidow Collection appeared in the first exhibition I curated at Arlington Museum of Art called Pure Paint.  Another early two-part piece, painting and wood, shows his affinity for duality in his work.  Becoming more connected to the digital world, he created the two small photo-based works from Dallas Contemporary’s print series in which every image is completely different.

76.piece_prompt: How do you see this figure relating to art history?
76.collector_notes: Fort Worth sculptor/teacher Chris Powell began his early work in ceramics.  The initial pieces in clay captured my imagination.  This elegant standing figure hearkens back to primitive time, standing as a sentry to welcome and beckon all who come near.  Its incised markings bear a strange language that adds to its mystery.  Endearingly we call the figure “Norman,” named by one of my sons, when it first stood in an earlier apartment entry hall.  Mimicking UTD President Dr Daniel’s view of a telling sign, “I’ll know the art is meaningful to its audience when someone proposes in front of Norman.”

35.piece_prompt: What does this silhouette tell you about being a woman?

36.piece_title: The Temptation of St. Anthony xxvi, the Sun
36.piece_prompt: What do you feel about this circle, knowing now that its made of blood?
36.collector_notes: Not exactly in the Texas contemporary art realm, but this is a powerful drawing by an artist and team I really respect.  Internationally known artist Tim Rollins works with less-advantaged students in New York City, teaching them poetry and art simultaneously.  I’m attracted to the drawn line and the blood-stained text, attracting me evermore strongly to the image.  What a great way to prepare at-risk children for the challenges of life by teaching them to express themselves artistically.

37.piece_prompt: How would you describe the black mass & delicate lines in this print?
37.collector_notes: Dallas artist Andrea Rosenberg must draw in her sleep!  Drawing is clearly her preferred mode of expression.  The flower is her subject forevermore, drawing it consistently and constantly.  Her line is gracious, fluid and poetic.  The flower takes on human potential in her hand, often floating on a large open ground.  In this expressive print, she compounds its blackness and intensifies it to be even more than black.

77.piece_prompt: What do the materials in this installation bring to mind?
77.collector_notes: In the early 1990s, Houston sculptor Dean Ruck produced a large-scale installation at the Arlington Museum of Art.  With metal fencing, he built an open cage equipped with a large motorized blade wildly kicking up soccer balls.  The encased room referenced a childhood playground as more chaotic than we fantasize from earlier days.  The spent and deflated dodge balls were then nailed to the rear wall as trophies of life’s damage.  At the exhibition’s close, Ruck nailed a batch of the crushed balls on my office wall in an X pattern:  “Here; these are for you!”  I chose not to repeat the X pattern, which seemed an invasion of an artist’s work nearby.

38.piece_prompt: How does this pensive figure speak to you?  Can you imagine a conversation?
38.collector_notes: One of the few Florida artists in this collection, Vina Schemer works in clay.  Her ceramic plate with a photograph enmeshed on its surface makes ceramics take on a new dimension.  The poignant image of a forlorn young girl reminds me of Anne Frank, the strong-willed young woman whose diary outlasts her short and tragic life endured under Hitler’s regime.

78.piece_prompt: How well do the hard-edged shapes and soft forms co-exist?  Do you feel harmony or tension?  What do you imagine the artist’s intentions were?
78.collector_notes: The work of Dallas artist Ludwig Schwarz runs the gamut of painting, sculpture, and installations.  Clearly working as a conceptual artist, he makes art that responds to his most poignant ideas of the moment.  Usually tongue in cheek, he thinks about something serious and funny simultaneously.  In this small rich painting he mixes free-form abstraction with hard edge painting all in the same artwork!  Artists traditionally don’t mix and match their styles, but in Schwarz’s hand, it works.

39.piece_prompt: What is the implied narrative and who are the characters in this photograph?
39.collector_notes: Austin photographer Jason Singleton happens to use the camera to document his clever ideas.  I had juried his artwork in an exhibition, 22 Austin Artists to Watch for the Austin Museum of Art.  In this photograph, Singleton’s made an installation on a fence to deal with a heartbroken affair.  When the plants grow enough to cover the fence, his hurt heart will be healed.  For all of us who love and lose a loved one, the artist’s message is extremely poignant.

40.piece_prompt: When contemplating this print, what reasons can you imagine to celebrate?
40.collector_notes: Native American artist Jaune Quick-to-See has built a rare reputation as both a woman and a Native American artist.  She addresses the aspects of her cultural life particular to her that help her audience pay attention to life as a minority.  In this print Smith reminds us of how many, many years artists have been making art on this planet.

80.piece_prompt: How does the video’s conclusion relate to your personal journey and daily tribulations?
80.collector_notes: Former Dallas artist Paul Slocum now lives and works in the New York area.  Before he left Dallas, he ran a smart, small gallery called And/Or showing inventive area talent.  Slocum’s own art is conceptual, clearly reflecting a clever mind filled with brilliant ideas.  In an early work, he devised a computer program to document someone’s birthday forever (ad infinitum).  In Last Chair, Slocum sits with his violin tapping his toe, patiently waiting for the opportunity to be the last sound in the musical rendition, which ends up causing great glee to all viewers.  They also serve who only stand and wait, comes to my mind, a poignant reminder from 17th century blind poet, John Milton.

41.piece_prompt: What ideas do the floating figures provoke?
41.collector_notes: As a young working artist, I cherished drawing the female human form and was attracted to figurative work.  Early in my curating history, I found the drawings and prints of a young Rudolfo Lailson Sotelo seductive.  In a delicate, trained hand, he captured the figure in dreamlike scenarios that related to his Latino heritage.

81.piece_prompt: How does the darkness of the photograph affect its message?

42.piece_prompt: What elements and details of nature are evoked when looking at this photographic image?
42.collector_notes: Photographer Ann Stautberg, now living in Galveston, does more than make art as a photographer.  She creates strange, mysterious native Texas settings and dark interiors by hand-tinting her black-and-white photographs with oil crayons.  She used to work in a large commercial photo lab at night when it was closed to the public.  Stautberg names her works with diarist no-nonsense information about when and where she made the images.  In this haunting photograph, she captures her mother-in-law’s milestone birthday by highlighting all the candles on the cake and the reflections on her glasses.  She and husband/artist Frank Tolbert gave me this stunning print as a gift for my demi-century birthday.

43.piece_prompt: What elements in this reflected window signal the viewer about time?
43.collector_notes: San Antonio artist Suzi Vogel uses found materials to make her sculpture.  In this intimate display box, her selected collection of watches takes the viewer into a private world.  The antique quality of the box and the mystery of now worn timepieces set a stage for contemplation about the concept of time, its reality, and its passing.

44.piece_prompt: Does the handiwork, craft materials & title evoke ideas of “home”.?
44.collector_notes: Dallas artist David Willburn makes art out of intimate, delicate materials.  His drawn line is made with thread.  His small-scale works bring the viewer into his tidy, little constructed world of home and personal concerns.  Willburn is one of two male artists in the collection who choose needle and thread with which to draw.  As a young girl, I gained great pleasure from sewing that could’ve taken me down a different life path.

45.piece_prompt: How do the merging figures affect how you see the group?  Can you still experience them as individuals?
45.collector_notes: Expressive figurative painter Hiram Williams, now deceased, taught at the University of Texas for years before moving to Florida.  While studying for my MFA in painting at the University of Florida, Williams was my lead professor and became my beloved mentor.  He taught me a great deal about what makes good art.  There are a number of his works in the collection.  Williams actually painted Joni’s Chorus Line in class as a demonstration, removed it from the wall, named it and gave it to me!  The other Chorus Line was painted while he taught in Texas; large-scale drawings were an essential part of his oeuvre.  At the high point in Williams’ career, while showing in New York City, his work was purchased by the Whitney and MOMA, and then disappointingly his career lost momentum when his N Y gallery went bankrupt.  One of the books he wrote, How I Teach Painting, enjoyed a long publication run.

46.piece_prompt: Unstretched canvas diverges from the expected format of a painting – How does it modify your consumption of the image?
46.collector_notes: Expressive figurative painter Hiram Williams, now deceased, taught at the University of Texas for years before moving to Florida.  While studying for my MFA in painting at the University of Florida, Williams was my lead professor and became my beloved mentor.  He taught me a great deal about what makes good art.  There are a number of his works in the collection.  Williams actually painted Joni’s Chorus Line in class as a demonstration, removed it from the wall, named it and gave it to me!  The other Chorus Line was painted while he taught in Texas; large-scale drawings were an essential part of his oeuvre.  At the high point in Williams’ career, while showing in New York City, his work was purchased by the Whitney and MOMA, and then disappointingly his career lost momentum when his N Y gallery went bankrupt.  One of the books he wrote, How I Teach Painting, enjoyed a long publication run.

47.piece_medium: charcoal, mixed media on paper, fr
47.piece_prompt: How does scale affect the impact of this portrait?
47.collector_notes: Expressive figurative painter Hiram Williams, now deceased, taught at the University of Texas for years before moving to Florida.  While studying for my MFA in painting at the University of Florida, Williams was my lead professor and became my beloved mentor.  He taught me a great deal about what makes good art.  There are a number of his works in the collection.  Williams actually painted Joni’s Chorus Line in class as a demonstration, removed it from the wall, named it and gave it to me!  The other Chorus Line was painted while he taught in Texas; large-scale drawings were an essential part of his oeuvre.  At the high point in Williams’ career, while showing in New York City, his work was purchased by the Whitney and MOMA, and then disappointingly his career lost momentum when his N Y gallery went bankrupt.  One of the books he wrote, How I Teach Painting, enjoyed a long publication run.

48.piece_prompt: Is it possible for time to “stand still” or be captured?
48.collector_notes: Austin artist Steve Wiman is an assemblage artist who lived in Dallas for a time, but now owns the wonderfully curated Austin antique store, Uncommon Objects.  Wiman collects things and puts them together in inventive, curious ways.  He makes art from found materials.  The poetry of his work is how he marries the objects he assembles.in his assemblages.  Time in a Bottle is one of a few time-related works in the collection, dealing with the poignancy of time.  Oh, that we could really collect time in a bottle!

49.piece_medium: rubber, polyurethane, faux calla lilies, flocking
49.collector_notes: Now living in Galveston, sculptural artist Ann Wood sports a delightful sense of humor in her art-making.  When I first saw her work in San Antonio, I was captivated by its unusual collection of objects and marriage of materials.  As a recent graduate from fashion school in Dallas, Wood created a large-scale site-specific piece at Dallas Contemporary of luscious fake fruits cascading from the ceiling, making the viewer experience the possibility of walking through the Garden of Eden.

79.piece_title: untitled from series A Place like Home
79.piece_medium: Duratrans light box, photograph, glass, 2 lights
79.piece_prompt: Does this image relate to current events as well as history?
79.collector_notes: Israeli artist Danny Yahav-Brown came to Texas to study in the Glassell School’s CORE program in Houston.  While visiting his studio, I was taken with his experimental work in photography.  Soon after this studio visit, I included his work in an exhibition at Dallas Contemporary presenting new approaches to photography.  The playfulness and mysterious quality of his imagery continues to “wink” at me to this day.  Even in today’s world of scattered peoples, the simplicity of creating a home seems so idyllic and yet so essential.
